DOC.brief_summary: This is a randomized controlled trial to investigate the effect of cataract surgery on the household economy of cataract patients in rural area of Southern China.
DOC.brief_title: Impact of Cataract Surgery to Household Economy in Rural Area
DOC.detailed_description: Cataract is the leading cause of visual impairment worldwide and surgery is the only effective treatment. Previous studies show that visual impairment impacts the patient's socioeconomic status. However, how cataract surgery affects the economic status of patients in rural area of China has not been determined before. In the investigators study, cataract patients in rural area of Southern China will be enrolled and randomly divided into two groups. Cataract surgery will be performed in 4 weeks in intervention group, while performed at 1 year later in control group. The annual personal income by work, annual household income, hours in paid and unpaid work in the previous month, real estate ownership, household expenditures and quality of life will be investigated before and 1 year after surgery. Then, the difference in household economic and quality of life change between two groups at 1 year later will be assessed.
DOC.criteria: Agerelated cataract patients aged over 50 with best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) 0.3 or worse in the better eye. History of previous significant eye disease, including corneal pathology, uveitis, glaucoma, retina pathology, ocular trauma, or intraocular surgery. Cases in need of expedited surgery, including shallow anterior chamber (anterior chamber depth less than 2 mm), blindness of grade IV and V (BCVA worse than 0.02 in better eye) and intumescent and hypermature stage of cortical cataract. Systemic disease dampening activity and mobility, including cardiocerebro vascular diseases, hemiplegia, Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. Patients not willing to participate in the study.
